data.text: Knee Pain when Cycling: Any Advice or Encouragement?

**EDIT - I decided to take an indefinite break. Thanks for all the suggestions, will leave this post here for future searches*** Anyone have advice or encouragement for dealing with knee pain on tour? I did 5 days in TX earlier this Spring and on day 5 my knees flared up and I limped over the finish line. I was hoping this was just due to too much, too fast. I‚Äôm currently in day 3 of a projected multi-week ride. They are giving me a ton of trouble, specifically on the front of my knee. With riding they eventually warm up and become more of an annoyance than showstopper, but if I take any break from pedaling they are on fire when I start moving again. I am hoping they will settle down once my body adjusts but I‚Äôm a bit concerned this is going to push me off the road just as I am getting started. (And yes, I realize the ideal answer is ‚Äústop riding and go see a doctor, dummy‚Äù, but that isn‚Äôt an option right now)

My husband had some knee pain on his first tour. What fixed him was making sure he only pulled up on the pedals, clipped in of course. Whenever he focuses too much on pushing then knee pain flares up again. He also does some exercises like laying flat and then pushing his knees up and down or something... You probably want to check out some sort of a sports PT person.
data.author: Daisy Philtron

data.text: I‚Äôm using flats, so hopefully can get outfitted at the next bike shop
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: there are lots of bike shops in port Townsend, I think you are headed there soon based on your route.
data.author: Daisy Philtron

data.text: Be sure to ride slow and easy - low gears and spinning.
data.author: Kent Robinson

data.text: I‚Äôm practically crawling, especially with all the stops.

data.text: hang in there. I usually only average about 10kph including stops

data.text: Try some
data.author: Jim Connelley

data.text: I had trouble with my knees on tour in Texas hill country - Knee supports, anti inflammatories, spin more don't grind, ice knees if available in the evening
data.author: Julie Lovegrove

data.text: I'm a licensed massage therapist. If you foam roll and then stretch your quads it will help this a lot. Even better if you have access to a hot tub and/or a massage therapist. I had this at the beginning of ski season last year- I telemark, so lots of deep knee bends followed by a push, kind of like biking. I diligently massaged and stretched my quads and it went away. Good luck!
data.author: Julie Clemons

data.text: Whenever I get knee pain, I check my saddle height. I‚Äôve had to make minor adjustments with that over the years. But, maybe that‚Äôs a simple answer that you‚Äôve already checked‚Ä¶. What about getting into a routine of stretching before and after your ride? It may not be your knee, but something else that‚Äôs attached and that just happens to be where your pain is located üßê Don‚Äôt push big gears, that‚Äôll exacerbate it.
data.author: Nicole Rene

data.text: And, grab a tennis ball or something you can roll your legs out with- do some self massage
data.author: Nicole Rene

data.text: Can become a chronic illness. Better visit a doc, asap.
data.author: Mike Koslowski

data.text: Saddle height, saddle position, knee warmers, arnicare
data.author: Nick Stephens

data.text: Hi Sam, i get pain there if my saddle is too high. Saddle is the right height if you can pedal with your heels (try stationary, pedal backwards with your heels, preferably near a mirror so you can see that your hips aren't moving)
data.author: Aisling Mathews

data.text: Get a proper bikefit at the next bike shop, as other people have said, saddle height is vital for the knees, too high or too low will cause pain.
data.author: Steven Hawkswell

data.text: Come back to Voltaire
data.author: Stefan Zborowski

data.text: front knee pain maybe saddle a little low and/or to much forward
data.author: Konrad Fersterer

data.text: I had knee pain issues for years and got fitted too, blah blah blah. That usually dealt with the saddle adjustments you're already aware of. The final fix that has worked wonders for me was to get fitted by a laser alignment system. This made it obvious how my knees were not lining up with my pedals correctly and 1/2" spacers to push my pedals outward have made a WORLD of difference. The icing on the top was that the laser alignment system was done by my Physical Therapist who specializes in bike fitting and so health insurance covered the cost of it all! I haven't had any knee pain at all since installing the spacers a couple of years ago.
data.author: Mike Masse

data.text: Yes, I too have a couple mm shims to pronate my foot just a tiny bit. As for saddle height would you believe 1/2 cm can make a difference. Make sure your saddle is slipping down slightly as you ride. If carbon carry a tine bit of carbon paste to add friction.
data.author: Thomas Herbert

data.text: I moved my saddle back to fix my knee pain. But the positioning must make sense though, be in a point of balance.
data.author: Arn√æ√≥r Logi Arnarson

data.text: Same issue. I take three Bayer a day (any NSAID will work) and it was fine in a few days.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: OTC painkillers and as much rest as possible. Besides that, go see a doctor, you dummy üòâ
data.author: Aaron Crawford

data.text: Use lower gears sooner on inclines.
data.author: Anne Winkler-Morey

data.text: Fot infrapatellar pain, try an infrapatellar strap or taping, takes some of the load off and stabilises the patella a little
data.author: Andrew Robinson

data.text: DMSO gel rub followed by Voltaren/Diclofenac. The DMSO allows the Diclofenac to penetrate better/quickly. This works for me....
data.author: Judy Cox Gamble

data.text: I‚Äôve dealt with knee pain in my right knee for years. Biking especially causes me trouble. I keep my mileage low while touring (30-40 miles per day) and try to stay until 2k ft in elevation gain. It has been a huge help to roll out my thighs with a massage roller. I use my water bottle while on tour. Put it on the ground, lie down on it and put all your weight on. Roll back and forth slowly ten times. I will do this on a picnic table while touring.
data.author: Katharine Armijo

data.text: Sounds like you're asking for a quick way to get rid of knee pain and you are riding right now and will not stop to rest. That's tough. Possibilities for quick and easy fixes: - pedals not wide enough, so outside of foot curls down, bending foot, and up to the knee. Get wider pedals. - Elastic knee brace of some sort. Or those tapes on side of legs and knee...but that's pricier. - pedal slower, and on lower gears. You look like you're under 30, so you might be more likely to pedal harder, than use a concept I've read called cadence....getting power by using a lower gear and spinning the pedals round and round more. - more frequent &/or longer breaks. -take pain killers and anti inflammatory tablets. If you were home and had more time, we could consider more things, like muscles balance, nutrition, crank length. And ultimately, it does need rest. And perhaps exercises to balance muscles and strength from foot to torso. Several knee pain articles and books by various coaches and drs say this. Soft tissue injuries are notoriously slow to heal and fix , and knee issues have contributions from feet to hip, even core strength. :(
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.text: Roll your ITB as the problem may not be in your knee. YouTube an exercise that you maybe able to do with bed roll. There are not quick fixes so be consistent and roll morning and night.
data.author: Garry James

data.text: ‚òùÔ∏è
data.author: Betsy Blake

data.text: Do you have any previous injuries?
data.author: Robert E Weeks

data.text: so many. But none like this. I had a separate knee issue from snowboarding that was resolved through time and PT, but it felt very different, different location, etc
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: I only ask because of my own knee problems. I tore an ACL years ago and the repair tendon was too tight so it has worn to bone on bone. I did my PT. I'm just wondering if you are early arthritis in the knee.
data.author: Robert E Weeks

data.text: I get knee pain every year when I do a tour, usually after about 3-5 days, it lasts for about 2-3 days and I just ride through it and then it go's away for the rest of the tour. I also get the same knee pain if I ever go on a long walk of about 15 miles or more
data.author: Jamie Newton

data.text: Lol.... Bike fit isn't limited to adjusting your saddle height.... It's also about the angle of your peddles, the length of the stroke of your crank, how the knee is aligned according to the forward, downward, and to stroke of your peddle cycle/stroke.
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: Hip flexor is too tight. Lookup couch stretch.
data.author: Corby Cobb

data.text: Shorter cranks. Almost all bikes come with cranks that are too long as standard.
data.author: Steve Howley

data.text:
I suffered from a bad knee a few years back brought on by cycling. Doing this fixed it but it took a week or so. https://youtu.be/o5b0gS7wI1k
Knee Pain Exercises - Physical Therapy For Knee Pain
youtube.com
data.author: Marshall Parsons

data.text: did you do this on the road or at home?
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: I did it after I limped home from a tour. During the tour I just had to baby it. Pop ibuprofen and take frequent breaks. It was only one knee and no way it was going to fix itself without some time off. But since I did the excercises I have been able to ride hard again without a recurrence.
data.author: Marshall Parsons

data.text: Sorry but is it possible that you are suffering from arthritis? Mine was poor lateral muscle development. But if it is both knees it may be some sort of inflammatory disease (not a doctor here). Taking anti-inflammatories before the pain starts works better than after. Good luck.
data.author: Marshall Parsons

data.text: Same problem. Still struggling. Recently a PT diagnosed it to be associated with piriformis syndrome. I am undergoing ultrasonic therapy on knee for oedema which I discovered in MRI, and IFT for both knee and ITB. Along with excercise and message. Seems to be working as of now. Long term results will be known after few months I got this pain while using 3x9 on my routine commute of 45km as an experiment. My usual ratios were either 2x6 or 3x7 after warmup on 2x5.
data.author: Balraj Singh

data.text: The best advice I can give is to get your primary care doc to give you a referral to a sports type physical therapist. Gods they are. I was on an AT thru-hike attempt when knee pain drove me off the trail. Doctors gave me drugs, but my PT found the root cause, and fixed it. Did I mention PTs are like gods on earth? Find a good one, get a referral, and go.
data.author: Bill Garlinghouse

data.text: Stretch your quads
data.author: Nbs Guy

data.text: I have knee pain due to full blown Osteoarthritis and being clipped in helps as I can pull more as opposed to push. I cannot walk far without pain but I can cycle all day long. Try different things like foot position if you are already running clip-less.
data.author: Hermann Kerr

data.text: My guess is that your saddle is too high, not too low. However, you say you already had a professional bike fit. I'd probably want to know about the fitter's professional qualifications, and exactly what as adjustments he made to your fit. If you're on flats, you should try clipless pedals, but then you need to make sure the fit is correct. Unfortunately, I don't have any other advice. If you consulted a doctor, they would tell you to ice it and rest it for several days, plus NSAID pain meds. There is literally nothing else you can do to treat it.
data.author: Larry Sanders

data.text: she is a physical therapist and specializes in / exclusively does cycling fit and PT
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: Well, if you're experiencing pain, then she didn't get it right. This isn't necessarily her "fault" as bike fit is often a matter of trial and error, and you weren't experiencing the problem when you had the fit done. I do note that most professional fitters recommend being clipped in because it relieves pressure on knees and butt.
data.author: Larry Sanders

data.text: Check for the bottom of the knee using a plum Bob to hang down to center of the ball of your foot in relation the axel of your pedal. If it forward move your saddle back, if it's back move your saddle forward.
data.author: Rene Douglas

data.text: Stay in lower gears and spin at a higher RPM. Pedal in the gear your weakest leg wants.
data.author: Kenneth Osterweil

data.text: Ibuprofen
data.author: Jeff Westerfield

data.text: The only time my knee isn‚Äôt killing me is when I‚Äôm on my bike.
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: Stretching! In 2017 I've bicycled from Switzerland to Oman. And in the first couple of weeks I had strong pain in my knees and thought I need to stop the trip. I went to see a sports doctor and he said that my knees are ok. I just need to stretch after the ride and should not wear tight pants etc over the knee area (not restricting the movement). It worked and I could continue the journey.

data.text: If you pedal while standing up does it hurt?
data.author: Tessa Pargiter-Hatem

data.text: I‚Äôll have to test today. What would it mean if it does/doesn‚Äôt hurt when standing up?
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: not a Doctor here, but getting this also when standing seems like very bad news.
data.author: David Muise

data.text: not a doctor either but when my friend and I toured the west coast he had horrible pain where you‚Äôre describing it and the pain went away if he was pedaling while standing / also when he really focused on his pedaling form. - he turned out to have bad tendinitis. So if you‚Äôre wearing clip in shoes, focusing on keeping your feet flat/ parallel to the ground and pulling up with the ball of your foot for the upward pedal motion, and pushing down for the downward motion. It focuses more of the tension on your muscles and less on your tendons I think.
data.author: Tessa Pargiter-Hatem

data.text: Based on what, if you don‚Äôt mind sharing.
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: same pain for 2 different ‚Äòuses‚Äô seems a bigger issue than a pain for just one. And I find that ‚Äôtired legs‚Äô seem less tired when I change to Standing. Not a lot of science in this though; I‚Äôm just inferring
data.author: David Muise

data.text: Loads of tips in this thread, and I have tried almost all of them over the years (I've had knee pain for 20 years and not just when cycling). For me the only thing that makes the pain from touring go away... is more touring! I'm on a long tour right now and the first two weeks were really bad. Then it gradually got better and I upped the daily effort slowly. After 6-8 weeks of daily riding it plateaued at a low and bearable level of pain.
data.author: Hugh Warrington

data.text: I had pain in the same spot, the seat post had crept down slowly over 500ks. What a difference a few mm can make.
data.author: Ben Jaminn

data.text: Pain relievers might be the fix for a short time. There is no drug that comes without some side effect. Check for the root cause of the inflammation. Decades of standard American diet? All the excess salt, fat and sugar will take its toll on our bodies. Some evidence based information about what you eat will put you way ahead of what doctors get in their education. I get it that you have to focus on the now. Think long term health by diet.
data.author: Tim Wygal

data.text: My pain in similar/same spot was worse running - and bad when pushing hard on pedals. With me it was tight quads and having to stretch them out. I hope you find a solution that works!
data.author: Rachael Holmes

data.text: My bike fitter told me that the setup was ‚Äòtheoretically correct‚Äô and that most riders would be fine, but to come back if I noticed any issues. I took that as an observation on the variations in human physiology and not as an admission of incompetence. Here I‚Äôd mark the saddle height, then try raising it 10 mm.
data.author: David Muise

data.text: @author it seems you‚Äôre exerting more than you practiced for such a long rides. Go to your practices exertion level to avoid further injury. What kind of drinks are you taking while on ride? Ride in medium to low gear to avoid straining. If possible lie on the ground on your back and air cycle with legs up in the air for half an hour.
data.author: Skyler Brown

data.text: I had knee pain in this area on a long tour. I met someone who had rehabiliated pro athletes with injuries and he grabbed my lower leg and foot and said your problem is in your foot and your calf. He pressed quite hard on a muscle in my calf (which hurt a lot) and then some points on the underside of my foot (which had me writhing around). He showed me how to release the muscle tightness and advised me to have legs covered qhile warming up. He massaged both areas and the pain in my knee went. Followed his advice and was fine afterwards. I was in my 20s then. These days I have different muscles that get tight and create pain in my knees and I stretch to stop the problem. The man who helped me then was Gordon Pirie, who was a long distance runner (1931-1991).I owe him a great deal.
data.author: Debbie Ellen

data.text: Get an MRI - I found I have firbromyalgia, and the pain is controlled with meds. Your result could point to the right treatment.
data.author: Anders du Ton

data.text: If its that location, it might be the patella tendon. I had problems with this too. For instant relief I used kinesio tape. Check youtube for "Patella tendon kinesio" how it's done. It helped me getting through my biking holiday. However, on the long run I had to rest and when the pain was gone ramping up the effort step by step not biking in pain.
data.author: Christian M√ºller

data.text: Look up patello-femoral pain syndrome and see if it applies to you. Treatment is generally stretching and strengthening
data.author: James Cameron

data.text: IF you have clip in pedals they may not suit you. I used them for more than 30y but had to quit 2y ago after a ruptured meniscus (due to age). I found that using flat BMX type pedals with flat shoes and mid-foot over pedal axle completely solved the problem. It won't slow you down!

data.text: - Quality 'quill' pedals w/half clips here! And older (comfortably walkable) 'touring' style shoes.

data.text: your no 2 scope?
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: Try spinning faster on a higher gear (up your cadence a little more than usual, and don't "grind" as hard). Grinding can kill your knees. Other things that have helped me: if you're using clipless pedals try loosening the release up a bit so that your feet can float and rotate a bit. And then saddle height, keep well hydrated, stretch out all of your lower body muscles everyday including your back. Good luck!
data.author: Jen Klaudinyi

data.text: Stretching and build muscle, i dont know the name in english , in spanish this muscle is called "vasto interno" , it is the muscle up and inside from the knee cap, it should get better over time if you dont push too hard, but this muscle takes longer to build up than others
data.author: Tomas Aperlo

data.text: STOP asking random strangers about medical issues on the internet, get to a doctor and then find a real professional bike fitter! (a good fitter will work through this with you AFTER the medical problem is ruled out)
data.author: Russ McCoy

data.text: I was just trying to save my tour. This trip has been a dream of mine and after so much preparation and money spent I‚Äôm absolutely gutted to pull the plug. As stated in the post, I did get a professional bike fit before I left, with an actual Physical Therapist. Obviously going the medical route (weeks/months) from a small town in coastal Washington isn‚Äôt a feasible solution to the immediate problem.
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: If I were having this issue while on tour, or for that matter, anytime, I'd stop riding until I got it sorted out so it wouldn't end my cycling completely.
data.author: Rob Schlumpberger

data.text: I have knee pain off and on, mostly when clipped in. I had a bike fitting they put washer between the crank & pedal to push the pedal out a little for me. When I am NOT clipped in I can move my foot around more on the pedal to change positions and can usually avoid the pain.
data.author: JonMar Koon

data.text: - One of several reasons I tried and rejected 'click in' Systems WAAAY back when! Always been a rider, on and off-road, not a racer.
data.author: Terry R Tweedy

data.text: Use a higher cadence, more pedaling but less force.
data.author: Pel Deal

data.text: When I had knee pains we changed out the pedals I was using to ones that gave me more float.
data.author: Kelly Davis

data.text: Therapeutic massage.
data.author: Rebecca Merica

data.text: If not been said, increase your cadence. Knee pain can be caused, especially with a loaded down bike, when you are pushing hard in a lower gear for long periods of time. Buy riding with a higher cadence, you will increase muscle strength around the knee and pain should go away.
data.author: Sergio Armani

data.text: The photo above is pointing to the patellar tendon and the diagnosis will likely be 'patellar tendonosis' which just means the tendon is damaged. The remedy will start with rest and Physical therapy (which for an already active person doesn't help much in this situation) but quads and glutes will be the focus. They may try tactics such as PRP which has some success but isn't perfect. There may also be a surgical offering to "clean it up a little" . Surgery of course isn't perfect, it's expensive, and will keep you sidelined for a bit. In your case I'd approach it with heat (wear a compression sleeve over your knee) and ice it after use. I'd eat anti inflammatory foods and take ibuprofen. I'd consider some placebo inducing products like collagen and or glucosamine because it may make you at least think it feels better for another day of riding over and over again. Best of luck to you and your bike rides and knees.
data.author: Ken Vogel

data.text: More morphine. üòé
data.author: Garron Allman

data.text: you got a connect? üòÇ
data.author: Sam Higgins

data.text: The nice thing about bikes, is that sometimes you can solve seemingly major issues quite easily just by changing your position. Because cycling is so repetitive, little tweaks in body position can sometimes make the difference between incapacitated and no pain. So here's how to be methodical about it: Take a few days off. -switch to flat pedals if using clips. -raise seat appreciably. See if you can cycle without pain. -lower seat appreciably. See if you can cycle without pain. -Change saddle position on seatpost or run to a bike shop and try out a setback seatpost. Fiddle with all these elements to see if there's a combination where you can cycle pain free. If not, it's time for an extended break and doctor's visit.
data.author: Brenna Sullivan

data.text: Glucosamine Ibuprofen Acetaminophen Ride an hour get off bike walk 10 minutes every hour after 12 days your body will adjust trust me I rode across the country with torn meniscus
data.author: Joseph Delagarza

data.text: Ice if you can find it. I have bursitis in my left knee that gets swollen when I do too many miles of anything. Ice and rest, but maybe ice alone will get you past your goal
data.author: Hector Gonzalez

data.text: I had knee problems as well. I did some very effective PT strengthening the muscles around the joint. Very helpful. I continue to do them while on tour.
data.author: Robin Brodsky

data.text: Flats!
data.author: Guy Stuart
